notes.text:
Red Hat OpenShift Service Mesh 2.4.2 Containers

Red Hat Product Security has rated this update as having a security impact of Important. A Common Vulnerability Scoring System (CVSS) base score, which gives a detailed severity rating, is available for each vulnerability from the CVE link(s) in the References section.
notes.title: Topic

notes.text:
Red Hat OpenShift Service Mesh is Red Hat's distribution of the Istio service mesh project, tailored for installation into an on-premise OpenShift Container Platform installation.

Security Fix(es):

* envoy: OAuth2 credentials exploit with permanent validity (CVE-2023-35941)

* envoy: Incorrect handling of HTTP requests and responses with mixed case schemes (CVE-2023-35944)

* envoy: CORS filter segfault when origin header is removed (CVE-2023-35943)

For more details about the security issue(s), including the impact, a CVSS score, acknowledgments, and other related information, refer to the CVE page(s) listed in the References section.
notes.title: Details

notes.text: A flaw was found in Envoy, where a malicious client can construct credentials with permanent validity in a specific scenario. This issue is caused by some rare scenarios, such as the combination of host and expiration time, in which the HMAC payload can always be valid in the OAuth2 filter's HMAC check.

notes.text: envoy: OAuth2 credentials exploit with permanent validity
notes.title: Vulnerability summary

vulnerabilities.title: envoy: OAuth2 credentials exploit with permanent validity

notes.text: A flaw was found in Envoy. Suppose an origin header is configured to be removed with request_headers_to_remove: origin. The CORS filter will segfault and crash Envoy when the origin header is removed and deleted between decodeHeaders and encodeHeaders.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: envoy: CORS filter segfault when origin header is removed

vulnerabilities.title: envoy: CORS filter segfault when origin header is removed

notes.text: A flaw was found in Envoy that allows for mixed-case schemes in HTTP/2. However, some internal scheme checks in Envoy are case-sensitive, leading to incorrect handling of requests and responses with mixed case schemes. For example, if a request with a mixed scheme HTTP is sent to the OAuth2 filter, it will fail the exact-match checks for HTTP and inform the remote endpoint the scheme is HTTP, thus potentially bypassing OAuth2 checks specific to HTTP requests.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: A flaw was found in Envoy, where a specifically crafted response from an untrusted upstream service can cause a denial of service through memory exhaustion. This issue is caused by Envoyâs HTTP/2 codec, which may leak a header map and bookkeeping structures upon receiving RST_STREAM immediately, followed by the GOAWAY frames from an upstream server.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: envoy: HTTP/2 memory leak in nghttp2 codec
